title: A Novel Integrated Magnetic Core Structure Suitable for Transformer-Linked Interleaved Boost Chopper Circuit
abstract: A novel integrated magnetic structure suitable for a transformer-linked interleaved boost chopper circuit is proposed in this paper. Coupled inductors with high coupling are known to be effective for downsizing magnetic components. However, it is difficult to obtain the optional leakage inductance with high coupling for coupled inductors with EE or EI cores because of the fringing effect in the air gap. In order to overcome this problem, a novel integrated magnetic structure is first proposed. Then, a design method for the coupled inductor with the proposed magnetic structure is introduced on the basis of the magnetic circuit model. Finally, the effectiveness of the novel magnetic core structure is validated and discussed from an experimental viewpoint.

A Novel Integrated Magnetic Core Structure Suitable for
Transformer-Linked Interleaved Boost Chopper Circuit
Jun Imaoka
∗
Student Member, Shota Kimura
∗
Student Member
Wilmar Martinez
∗
Non-member, Masayoshi Yamamoto
∗
Member
(Manuscript received Dec. 24, 2013, revised May 28, 2014)
A novel integrated magnetic structure suitable for a transformer-linked interleaved boost chopper circuit is proposed
in this paper. Coupled inductors with high coupling are known to be e ﬀective for downsizing magnetic components.
However, it is diﬃcult to obtain the optional leakage inductance with high coupling for coupled inductors with EE or
EI cores because of the fringing e ﬀect in the air gap. In order to overcome this problem, a novel integrated magnetic
structure is ﬁrst proposed. Then, a design method for the coupled inductor with the proposed magnetic structure is
introduced on the basis of the magnetic circuit model. Finally, the eﬀectiveness of the novel magnetic core structure is
validated and discussed from an experimental viewpoint.
Keywords: boost converter, coupled Inductors, high coupling coeﬃcient, fringing ﬂux, design, magnetic core structure
1. Introduction
High power density power converters are required in sev-
eral industry applications such as: automotive, military,
aerospace, renewable energies, computer power systems, in-
ter alia (1)–(10). Particularly, downsizing magnetic components
such as transformers and inductors is important because they
tend to occupy a signiﬁcant percentage of the full volume and
weight in the power converters. In addition, the demand of
base metals (Fe, Al, Cu, etc.) and rare metals (Ni, Mn, Co
etc.) that are used in magnetic cores will be raised because of
the world economic growing. Therefore, it is probable that
the price of these resources will be increased because of their
lack in the near future
(11) (12). In this way, downsizing magnetic
cores and saving metal resources are signiﬁcantly important.
In this context, in downsizing methods for power convert-
ers, interleaved topology is well known as one of the con-
verter types that can achieve higher power density in compar-
ison with conventional topologies
(13). This method presents
the advantages of high frequency current operation of the
output smoothing capacitor, attenuation of EMI contents and
reduction of ﬁlter size
(14)–(18). However, interleaved topology
requires many magnetic devices in proportion to the num-
ber of phases. Thus, this method is not eﬀ ective for down-
sizing the magnetic components. Consequently, integrated
magnetic components have been applied to power converter
including isolated, non-isolated DC-DC converters and PFC
converters
(19)–(26).
These integrated magnetic components consist of multi-
ple windings on a single magnetic core, where it is pos-
sible to share the magnetic ﬂux, contributing to downsize
the magnetic components. Additionally, due to the mutual
∗Shimane University
1060, Nishikawatsu, Matsue, Shimane 690-8504, Japan
induction, inductor ripple current operates at a higher fre-
quency in comparison with single phase converters (1)–(3) (10) (22).
Moreover, some references describe interleaved boost con-
verter proposing diﬀerent design methods for coupled induc-
tors that achieve high power density performance in power
conversion systems
(1)–(4) (10) (25) (26). In these previous studies,
coupled inductors with high coupling coe ﬃcient are e ﬀec-
tive for downsizing because the DC ﬂux can be cancelled and
inductor ripple current operates at a higher frequency. How-
ever, coupled inductors with high coupling coe ﬃcient using
EE or EI cores present diﬃculties in design and manufacture,
because of the fringing eﬀect, which is generated at the air
gap part of the mentioned cores
(1) (26) (28). In addition, a coupled
inductor with a large air gap causes additional winding losses
due to fringing ﬂux near the air-gap. Fringe ﬁeld wreaks eddy
currents in the windings when it tries to penetrate the wind-
ings, and causes deterioration of the power conversion e ﬃ-
ciency
(29) (30). Hence, improvement of inductor core structures
is necessary in order to achieve a high coupling coe ﬃcient
and high eﬃciency.
This paper presents a novel integrated magnetic structure
which can suppress fringing ﬂuxes in the air gap and achieve
a high coupling coeﬃcient. This proposed structure can also
obtain an optional leakage inductance with only a short air
gap length. In this way, the analysis and design method for
the coupled inductor with the novel magnetic core structure
is also introduced on the basis of a magnetic circuit model.
Finally, the validation of the design method for the proposed
coupled inductor and the fringing ﬂux reduction is discussed
on the basis of an experimental setup.
2. Transformer-linked Interleaved Boost Chop-
per Circuit with Coupled Inductor
2.1 Circuit Topology The interleaved boost chopper
circuit with a coupled inductor is shown in Fig. 1. Where Vi

A Integrated Magnetic Core Structure for Interleaved ConvertersʢJun Imaoka et al.ʣ
Fig. 1. Interleaved boost chopper circuit with coupled inductor
(a) Conventional structure (b) Magnetic circuit model
(c) Deﬁnition of each dimension
Fig. 2. Conventional coupled inductor with E-E core
and Vo are the input and output voltages, respectively. Co
is the output smoothing capacitor. Lc1 and Lc2 are the self-
inductances of each phase. Mc is the mutual inductance be-
tween the windings. The switches S 1 and S2 are switched
with a 180◦phase shift, and operate with the same duty ratio.
Due to the interleaved technique, this converter can reduce
the ripple voltage of the smoothing capacitor Co, compared
to a single phase boost converter (14) (15). Additionally, the pro-
posed circuit can reduce the current stress of power devices,
S1,S 2,D 1 and D2 because the input current is divided into
two phases without using power devices with high current
rating. Moreover, coupled inductor enables the integration
of magnetic components into only one assembly, where each
phase inductor currenti
1 and i2 operates at a higher frequency
because of the eﬀect of mutual induction. From these fea-
tures, the miniaturization of the whole converter and the low
cost of the magnetic components are achieved.
2.2 Inconvenient of EE and EI Core Structures for
Coupled Inductors First of all, it is necessary to exam-
ine the conventional structure of a coupled inductor and its
complications. A conventional coupled inductor, shown in
Fig. 2(a), is composed of leakage inductors and a transformer.
And also, an only air gap in the coupled inductor is located
in the center leg in order to obtain a high mutual inductance.
Due to the core structure, two advantages are provided: First,
the magnetizing current in the transformer hardly ﬂows due
to the higher mutual inductance. In this case, the inductor rip-
ple current becomes almost completely twice the frequency
as compared to single-phase boost converter
(26). And second,
the DC ﬂux is almost canceled by high coupling (2).F r o m
these features, this core structure is e ﬀective for downsizing
the magnetic components in the proposed circuit.
However, taking into account the coupled inductor shown
in Table 1 where a coupled inductor with two windings and an
air gap was made on the basis of reference (27), it is possible
Table 1. Problem of conventional magnetic core structure
Fig. 3. The magnetic ﬁeld simulation result
to infer that the implementation of this type of core struc-
ture causes some inconvenient. These inductance values are
measured by HIOKI 3522 LCR HiTESTER, and the mea-
sured frequency is 50 kHz. The measurement procedure of
the inductance is shown in the Sect. 1 of the appendix. As
seen in Table 1, the designed and measured inductance val-
ues were similar. The small diﬀerence between the designed
and measured value of the mutual inductance occurs by an
error between the designed and measured value of the mag-
netic reluctance in outer leg. In addition, this error appears
due to a tiny air gap at the junction of cores, although there is
no deliberate air gap in the outer leg.
However, there is a more serious problem, and it is that
the needed air gap lengths are quite diﬀerent: 1.75 mm in the
design and 26.6 mm in the experimental case. This problem
generates complications of the magnetic design and increases
winding losses due to fringing e ﬀect. Additionally, it is dif-
ﬁcult to achieve high coupling in the case of the structure
with EE or EI cores. In fact, since it is not possible to adjust
the coupling coeﬃcient, there is a case that cannot be created
a coupled inductor
(28). Therefore, magnetic core structures
which can increase the coupling coeﬃcient are required.
First of all, the cause which is not possible to improve the
coupling coeﬃcient is investigated by a magnetic ﬁeld sim-
ulation in the case of conventional structure. The result is
shown in Fig. 3. As seen in this ﬁgure, it is clear that there
are two causes: First, external leakage ﬂuxes of the winding
inﬂuence the inability to achieve a high coupling coe ﬃcient.
The amount of external leakage ﬂux has been known that is
to be related to the winding arrangement, and split-winding
396 IEEJ Journal IA, Vol.3, No.5, 2014

method or uniformly windings in the outer leg of the cores,
like toroid inductors have been well known as methods for
reducing the external leakage ﬂux
(1) (31).
Secondly, the fringing ﬂux at the air gap is also taken as
a one of these causes, as seen in Fig. 3. From a theoretical
viewpoint, the mechanism which cannot improve the cou-
pling coeﬃcient by fringing ﬂux is described as follows.

From another viewpoint, coupling coe ﬃcient is repre-

Therefore, the maximum coupling coe ﬃcient value depends
on the minimum R
mo values, or the relative permeability of
magnetic materials or the magnetic core structure.
As a conclusion, it was possible to corroborate that the
causes that cannot allow a high coupling coe ﬃcient are the
external leakage ﬂux of the inductor windings and the fring-
ing ﬂux at the air gap.
Then, the relationship between the coupling coeﬃcient and
the magnetic core structure is studied. Table 2 shows the re-
lationship between three di ﬀerent core structures and their
coupling coe ﬃcients (Another case of the loosely coupled
inductor is shown in Sect. 3 of the Appendix). In the case of
the loosely coupled structure with EE or EI cores, the max-
imum coupling coeﬃcient is close to 0.95. Therefore, if the
coupling coeﬃcient reaches its maximum value, the design-
ers of the coupled inductor have to make an air gap at the
transformer part as shown in Fig. 2(a) in order to obtain the
designed leakage inductance. However, this design method
comes up against the problem that the magnetizing current of
the transformer increases. This is because the mutual induc-
tance is fairly decreased
(1) (10). By contrast, the coupling coef-
ﬁcient is about 0.98 to 0.999 in the case of the close-coupled
inductor structure shown in Table 2. In this context, there is
a great constraint due to the designed leakage inductance is
not obtained because the desired structure does not permit it.
Accordingly, there is no structure which has coupling coeﬃ-
cients between 0.95∼0.98 in case of EC90 cores.
2.3 A Novel Integrated Magnetic Structure In this
section, a novel integrated magnetic core structure suitable
for coupled inductors which can achieve a high coupling co-
eﬃcient are proposed. Considering the circumstances men-
tioned above, a novel integrated magnetic structure, shown
in Fig. 4, is introduced in order to miniaturize the cross-
sectional area A
g for obtaining a higher coupling. The pro-
posed structure is composed of two E typed and one I typed
cores. The windings on the “winding” leg are inversely cou-
pled as shown in Fig. 4.
As attractive features of the novel magnetic core struc-
ture: it is possible to mention that the proposed structure can
achieve a high coupling coe ﬃcient and obtain an optional
397 IEEJ Journal IA, Vol.3, No.5, 2014
A Integrated Magnetic Core Structure for Interleaved ConvertersʢJun Imaoka et al.ʣ
Fig. 4. Proposed magnetic core structure (E-I-E core)
Fig. 5. Aim of proposed magnetic core structure
leakage inductance without a large air gap. In addition, it
is not possible to a ﬀect the external leakage ﬂux to the pe-
ripheral circuits as compared to the conventional structure
because it is covered in the both sides of magnetic core.
The aim of this structure is shown in Fig. 5. This structure
can achieve the miniaturization of the sectional areaA
g in the
air gap by shortening the distance between each phase wind-
ing, x. By this core structure, the fringing ﬂux can be sup-
pressed by adjusting the distance between each phase wind-
ing. If the maximum coupling coeﬃcient of the conventional
structure is saturated, the novel core structure is useful, and
the magnetizing current in the transformer hardly ﬂows be-
cause of the presence of a high mutual inductance.

Fig. 11. Design procedure for a novel coupled inductor
3.2 Design for Novel Coupled Inductor In this sec-
tion, the design method for the proposed coupled inductor is
introduced. And the design procedure of the novel coupled
inductor is also proposed as shown in Fig. 11. The design
procedure is assumed using “general-purpose cores” because
they are easy-access for typical users. The design procedure
is composed of 9 steps as shown in Fig. 11. As a case study,
we design and experiment the novel coupled inductor to con-
ﬁrm the validity of the design method and the e ﬀectiveness
of the coupled inductor.
Step 1: Experimental parameters are shown in Table 3.
The designed ripple current I
Lpp is 1 A.
Step 2: The core size is selected considering mounting
space of the inductor on PCBs (Printed Wiring Board), and
the speciﬁcation of prototype core is shown in Table 4. The
two E cores in EE50-Z and one I core in EI50-Z are selected
as for this prototype. The core material of the prototype is
ferrite (Material: PC40, Supplier: TDK CO., LTD) because

Step 3: Then, “minimum” magnetic reluctance in the

former part. In addition, higher mutual inductance value
contributes to reduce the leakage inductance value which is
proportional to the amount of DC ﬂux in the core, if inductor
ripple current presents the same value with non-coupled in-
ductor. Therefore, higher coupling contributes downsizing
magnetic components. The minimum magnetic reluctance

μr −1 ·(2 ·Rlk ·μr ·μ0 ·Ac −lc) ··········· (20)
As a result, the air gap length of 2.5 mm was calculated.
Step 9:Based on this design process, the coupled inductor
constructed for this study is shown in Fig. 12. In addition,
Table 5 shows the speciﬁcation of the design and measured
values. The small di ﬀerence between the designed and mea-
sured value of the mutual inductance is occurred by an error
between the designed and measured value of the magnetic re-
luctance in the winding leg. In addition, the error of air gap
length between the designed the measured value is consider-
ably decreased as compared to conventional structures. Con-
cerning the winding arrangement, if the windings are coiled
intensively on coupled inductor with conventional structure,
coupling coe ﬃcient does not increase due to the inﬂuence
of external leakage ﬂuxes
(31). In the experimental case for the
proposed structure, although the winding is coiled intensively
in the winding leg, the coupling coeﬃcient was achieved with
a value of 0.968, which is a diﬃcult value in case of conven-
tional structures.
Concerning about the di ﬀerence of the air gap length be-
tween Tables 1 and 5, Although conventional coupled induc-
tor shown in Table 1 presents the error of about 15 times or
more between the designed and measured value of air gap
length, but the error of the air gap in the proposed structure
can be reduced to about 2 times or less.
In addition, as a reason why absolute lengths of the air gap
are diﬀerent between the Tables 1 and 5 is diﬀerent: the size
Table 5. Designed and measured parameter for the cou-
pled inductor
Fig. 13. Experimental waveforms of interleaved boost
chopper circuit with novel coupled inductor. Wherev
s1 is
the voltages of S1,a n di1 is the inductor current of phase 1
of the two evaluated cores is di ﬀerent. However, it does not
deny the eﬀectiveness of the proposed structure, even taking
into account the diﬀerence in the core size.
4. Experimental Results
In order to evaluate the proposed coupled inductor, the in-
terleaved boost converter with the coupled inductor prototype
was constructed. Additionally, the prototype converter was
equipped with average current balanced control, in order to
prevent DC bias magnetism
(32).
The experimental waveforms are shown in Fig. 13, where
it is possible to infer that the measured value of peak to peak
amplitude of inductor current is 1 A. In this way, the proposed
design is validated due to the measurements are correspond-
ing to the design values. In addition, inductor ripple current
has become almost twice the switching frequency because the
magnetizing current hardly ﬂows by high mutual inductance.
The current behavior contributes to the reduction of the RMS
value of inductor current because magnetizing current hardly
ﬂows, improvement of power conversion e ﬃciency will ex-
pect in comparison with a conventional structure, if it cannot
achieve higher coupling coe ﬃcient. In addition, magnetic
saturation has not occurred.
5. Conclusion
A novel integrated magnetic structure suitable for
transformer-linked interleaved DC/DC converter was pro-
posed in this paper. High frequency inductor ripple cur-
rent and reducing fringing ﬂux in the core were achieved by
using the proposed magnetic structure. Moreover, the de-
sign method of the novel coupled inductor was established.
401 IEEJ Journal IA, Vol.3, No.5, 2014
A Integrated Magnetic Core Structure for Interleaved ConvertersʢJun Imaoka et al.ʣ
Finally, the validation of the design method was conﬁrmed
from experimental results.

Appendix
1. Measurement Method for Each Inductance
In this section, the measurement method for the leakage
inductance and the mutual inductance of coupled inductors
is introduced. Each inductance is measured by changing the
winding connection. The winding connection methods are
shown in app. Fig. 1.
First of all, Self-inductance L
1 of phase 1 is measured by
opening another winding as shown in app. Fig. 1(a). Simi-
larly, self-inductance L
2 in phase 2 also can be measured by
this winding conﬁguration.
Then, each winding is connected as inverse coupling as
shown in app. Fig. 1(b). In this case, measured inductance La
is shown as follows based on Faraday’s law:
La =L1 +L2 −2M =Llk1 +Llk2 ··············· (A1)
Although this winding arrangement is able to measure to-
tal leakage inductance in each phase, the di ﬀerence between
leakage inductances in each phase cannot measure.
Finally, each winding is connected by direct coupling as
shown in app. Fig. 1(c).
La =L1 +L2 +2M ···························· (A2)
By using (A1), (A2), mutual inductance M value can be
obtained.
M =Lb −La
4 ································· (A3)

3. Another Case of the Structure and Coupling Coef-
ﬁcient
To conﬁrm the validity of the Table 2 and to improve reli-
ability in this paper, we measured the relationship between
the coupling coe ﬃcients and magnetic core structure with
PC40EE50 cores as another case. PC40EE50 is almost the
same size with the prototype with novel magnetic core struc-
ture. The core for measuring the maximum coupling coe ﬃ-
cient is shown in app. Fig. 2. The core which is eliminated
center leg shows the coupling coe ﬃcient value 0.94, and
leakage inductance is saturated at 136μH. If designers would
like to obtain lower inductance than this, coupled inductor
with the novel magnetic core structure is e ﬀective. From
these results, the validity of Table 2, and the e ﬀectiveness
of the novel magnetic core structure is conﬁrmed.
Jun Imaoka (Student Member) received the B.S. and M.S. degrees
in electrical and electronic engineering from Shimane
University, Shimane, Japan, in 2011 and 2013 respec-
tively. He is currently working toward the Ph.D. de-
gree in electronic function and system engineering in
Shimane University, Shimane, Japan. His research
interests include design of magnetic components and
modeling for high power density DC /DC converters
and AC/DC converters.
Shota Kimura (Student Member) received the B.S. degree electri-
cal and electronic system engineering from Shimane
University, Shimane, Japan, in 2013. Since 2013, he
is master candidate student in Shimane University.
He is interested in magnetic design and core losses
analysis for high power density DC/DC converter.403 IEEJ Journal IA, Vol.3, No.5, 2014
A Integrated Magnetic Core Structure for Interleaved ConvertersʢJun Imaoka et al.ʣ
Wilmar Martinez (Non-member) received the B.S. degree in elec-
tronic engineering and the M.Sc. degree in electrical
engineering from Universidad Nacional de Colom-
bia in 2011 and 2013, and is currently pursuing the
Ph.D. degree in electronic function and system engi-
neering with Shimane University, Japan. His current
research interests include losses estimation in power
converters and high power density DC-DC converters
for Electric Vehicles.
Masayoshi Yamamoto (Member) received the M.S. and Ph.D. de-
grees in science and engineering from Yamaguchi
University, Yamaguchi, Japan in 2000 and 2004 re-
spectively. From 2004 to 2005, he was with Sanken
Electric Co., Ltd., Saitama, Japan. Since 2006, he
has been with Shimane University, Shimane, Japan.
His research interests include power supply for HEV
(boost converter, buck converter, 3-phase inverter,
digital control), charging system for EV , LED illumi-
nation system for a tunnel, EMI of switching power
supply, and wireless power transfer.
